results.abstract: Gerald Jonas reviews books The Children Star by Joan Slonczewski, Bloom by Wil McCarthy, The Alien Years by Robert Silverberg and Last Summer At Mars Hill by Elizabeth Hand (M)

headline.main: Science Fiction

results.snippet: Despite their obvious differences -- mystery stories unpack the past, science fiction addresses the future -- the two genres have one thing in common. Both often challenge the reader to solve a puzzle that is posed early and kept in view throughout...
results.lead_paragraph: Despite their obvious differences -- mystery stories unpack the past, science fiction addresses the future -- the two genres have one thing in common. Both often challenge the reader to solve a puzzle that is posed early and kept in view throughout the narrative: Who killed Roger Ackroyd? What is the dominant species on this planet? Since such questions can typically be answered in a few declarative sentences, the more memorable stories focus not so much on what is revealed but on the circumstances of the revelation and its meaning for the people involved. THE CHILDREN STAR (Tor/Tom Doherrty, $24.95), by Joan Slonczewski, is a puzzle story that moves towards its denouement at a glacial pace but with unequivocal force. The planet Prokaryon can barely support human life. Its very undesirability makes it a bargain for the child-catchers of the Sacred Order of the Spirit, who scour the galaxy for orphans to raise at their underfunded Prokaryon mission. Little by little it appears that the dominant species on the planet may not be the human settlers after all; in ruling out native intelligence, the original colonists apparently failed to look closely or deeply enough.

results.abstract: Air Force Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps program, science elective, is introduced at Mount Vernon High School in Mount Vernon, NY; photo (M)

headline.main: R.O.T.C. Arrives at Mt. Vernon High School

results.snippet: SERGEANT HYMES, please come to the main office.'' That boomed over the intercom system throughout the sprawling building of Mount Vernon High School just before the start of the new school year.  Along with this simple request came a new science...
results.lead_paragraph: SERGEANT HYMES, please come to the main office.'' That boomed over the intercom system throughout the sprawling building of Mount Vernon High School just before the start of the new school year. Along with this simple request came a new science elective course and lofty expectations that the sky will be the only limit to the opportunities available to the 2,400 students here. Last month, an Air Force Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps program was introduced at the high school. Retired Master Sgt. James E. Hymes and the program's superior officer, Retired Lieut. Col. John F. Kirk, are responsible for running and teaching the unit aerospace science.

results.abstract: Russia will sell US up to all its allotted research time aboard first phase of international space station for $60 million, in concession born of country's financial crisis; deal, which theoretically reduces Russia's role to that of builder but not user of biggest space project, would help keep nation's faltering space program alive and its scientists engaged and presumably not looking for foreign work, which is major goal of arms controllers in Clinton Administration; accord is first time Russia has agreed to scale back its use of planned international outpost since it joined venture five years ago (M)

headline.main: To Buy Some Time, Russia to Sell U.S. Some Time in Space

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: In a concession born of crisis, Russia has agreed to sell the United States up to all its allotted research time aboard the first phase of the International Space Station for $60 million, NASA officials say.    In theory, the deal reduces Russia's...
results.lead_paragraph: In a concession born of crisis, Russia has agreed to sell the United States up to all its allotted research time aboard the first phase of the International Space Station for $60 million, NASA officials say. In theory, the deal reduces Russia's role to that of a builder but not a user of the biggest space project, at least during its many years of orbital assembly. But the sale would help keep Russia's faltering space program alive and its scientists engaged in the project, and presumably not searching for foreign work -- a major goal of arms controllers in the Clinton Administration.

results.abstract: Margaret Mary Ray, woman who was repeatedly jailed for stalking David Letterman over last decade, commits suicide by kneeling in front of speeding train in western Colorado; photo (M)

headline.main: The Woman Who Stalked Letterman Is a Suicide

results.snippet: The woman who was repeatedly jailed for stalking David Letterman over the last decade committed suicide on Monday by kneeling in front of a speeding train in western Colorado, the police said.     ''The conductor saw her run out on the railroad...
results.lead_paragraph: The woman who was repeatedly jailed for stalking David Letterman over the last decade committed suicide on Monday by kneeling in front of a speeding train in western Colorado, the police said. ''The conductor saw her run out on the railroad tracks,'' said Fred McKee, the undersheriff of Delta County in southwest Colorado.

results.abstract: Ohio Gov George V Voinovich, Republican, is leading Democrat Mary O Boyle in race to succeed US Sen John Glenn, Democrat who is retiring; photos (M)

headline.main: Republican Leads Race for Glenn's Senate Seat

results.snippet: The last time George V. Voinovich ran for office, he won re-election as Ohio's Governor with 72 percent of the vote, stunning even his most optimistic supporters and setting a 20th-century record for victory margins in Ohio politics.    This year,...
results.lead_paragraph: The last time George V. Voinovich ran for office, he won re-election as Ohio's Governor with 72 percent of the vote, stunning even his most optimistic supporters and setting a 20th-century record for victory margins in Ohio politics. This year, Mr. Voinovich, a Republican who is barred from seeking a third consecutive term, is running again, this time for the Senate seat held by John Glenn, a Democrat who is retiring.

results.abstract: Warner Brothers is re-releasing restored version of The Wizard of Oz at nearly 1,900 theaters nationwide on eve of movie's 60th anniversary; photo of Judy Garland; director Bryan Singer comments on Apt Pupil, his latest film based on Stephen King novella; writer Aaron Sorkin comments on Sports Night, television program he created for ABC about late-night sports show; photo (M)

headline.main: AT THE MOVIES

results.snippet: Revisiting Oz 6 Decades Later       The song ''Over the Rainbow'' was almost cut. Judy Garland was not the studio's choice, with some executives preferring Shirley Temple or Deanna Durbin. One director after another -- including King Vidor and...
results.lead_paragraph: Revisiting Oz 6 Decades Later The song ''Over the Rainbow'' was almost cut. Judy Garland was not the studio's choice, with some executives preferring Shirley Temple or Deanna Durbin. One director after another -- including King Vidor and George Cukor -- was replaced. The film itself was highly expensive, for 1939, costing $2.7 million. Whatever its original problems, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's ''Wizard of Oz,'' directed by Victor Fleming, remains perhaps the most inspired film musical ever. It is certainly the most enduring, with a record 23 airings on network television.

results.abstract: Profile of flutist Eugenia Zukerman, author and CBS correspondent, who is slated to perform in recital, accompanied by pianist Anthony Newman, at J C C on the Palisades in Tenafly, NJ; photo (M)

headline.main: Morning TV, Evening Recital: Just Another Day

results.snippet: ON ''CBS News Sunday Morning,'' the celebrated flutist and elegant correspondent Eugenia Zukerman is doing her weekly segment, this one about the pianist Yves Thibaudet. She says audiences love him and he's popular with his peers; she praises his...
results.lead_paragraph: ON ''CBS News Sunday Morning,'' the celebrated flutist and elegant correspondent Eugenia Zukerman is doing her weekly segment, this one about the pianist Yves Thibaudet. She says audiences love him and he's popular with his peers; she praises his technique, his way of conjuring colors. ''He brings out the hidden magic,'' she adds. Most of this is true of Ms. Zukerman as well, with some extras. She writes books, directs a music festival, has made 19 recordings, gives regular recitals at the New York Public Library, has beaten a dangerous lung disease, and still has what it takes to work for CBS -- and to perform in Tenafly tonight.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH: F. Story Musgrave; Watching From Sidelines as NASA Regains Spotlight

results.snippet: It was a sweltering recent autumn afternoon and F. Story Musgrave, 63, physician, poet, sky diver and now former astronaut, was sitting in a Florida hotel room and fiddling with a recalcitrant air-conditioner. ''I'll get this going in a flash,''...
results.lead_paragraph: It was a sweltering recent autumn afternoon and F. Story Musgrave, 63, physician, poet, sky diver and now former astronaut, was sitting in a Florida hotel room and fiddling with a recalcitrant air-conditioner. ''I'll get this going in a flash,'' declared Dr. Musgrave, the former space walker. ''I'm real good at fixing things.''

results.abstract: In this lesson, students evaluate the notion of aging by evaluating some of the studies that will be occurring on the next space shuttle mission, on which 77-year-old John Glenn is an astronaut. Students will then read an article containing a conversation with F. Story Musgrave, who retired from the space program upon NASA's urging due to his age (62), and analyze his views of NASA and John Glenn's participation in the program.

results.abstract: Behind excitement of scheduled spaceflight of Sen John Glenn is quiet apprehension about hidden dangers; even though safety experts agree that space shuttles must run regularly or become balky and their launching crews rusty, shuttles have flown little of late and Glenn's flight is regarded, in theory, as unusually risky; NASA, in response, is taking extra precautions to offset any dangers--though some private experts say odds of disaster still might be unusually high; photo; chart (M)

headline.main: On the Eve of Glenn's Shuttle Flight, Concerns Over a Lull in Launchings

results.snippet: Behind the excitement of the coming spaceflight of Senator John Glenn is quiet apprehension about hidden dangers.    Safety experts agree that the space shuttles, like temperamental hot rods, must run regularly or become balky and their launching...
results.lead_paragraph: Behind the excitement of the coming spaceflight of Senator John Glenn is quiet apprehension about hidden dangers. Safety experts agree that the space shuttles, like temperamental hot rods, must run regularly or become balky and their launching crews rusty. But the shuttles have flown little of late. So Senator Glenn's flight is seen, at least in theory, as unusually risky.

results.abstract: NASA engineers are optimistic about plans to have two satellites make joint observations of Sun; are working to reactivate Solar and Heliospheric Observatory, which has been off-line for four months, and say spacecraft will probably be ready for mutual studies of Sun with Spartan satellite to be carried aloft by shuttle Discovery on Oct 29; photos (L)

headline.main: Two Satellites to Study Sun During Discovery Mission

results.snippet: In spite of past problems, NASA engineers say they are optimistic about plans to have two satellites make joint observations of the Sun during the next space shuttle mission.    Engineers working to reactivate a troubled solar observatory say the...
results.lead_paragraph: In spite of past problems, NASA engineers say they are optimistic about plans to have two satellites make joint observations of the Sun during the next space shuttle mission. Engineers working to reactivate a troubled solar observatory say the craft will probably be ready for mutual studies of the Sun with a satellite carried aloft by the shuttle Discovery, scheduled to take off with a crew of seven on Oct. 29.

results.abstract: Game Theory column evaluates Zero Zero, interactive CD-ROM from Rhinestone Publishing; photos (M)

headline.main: From a French Past, a Look at the Future

results.snippet: PINKEE was born far away, in Paris, at a time when a fire burned in every grate and smoke curled black and feathery like a horse's tail from a thousand chimney pots.''    So begins the tale of a little girl in the City of Lights on New Year's Eve in...
results.lead_paragraph: PINKEE was born far away, in Paris, at a time when a fire burned in every grate and smoke curled black and feathery like a horse's tail from a thousand chimney pots.'' So begins the tale of a little girl in the City of Lights on New Year's Eve in 1899, ''the hinge upon which the century turned.'' Zero Zero, an interactive story on CD-ROM by Theresa Duncan, describes Pinkee's journey through the streets of Paris in the waning hours of the 19th century as she hops from rooftop to rooftop, explores the catacombs and slides down cartoon chimneys to ask whimsically drawn Parisians what the future has in store.

results.abstract: Clyde Haberman NYC column discusses reaction of middle age and older people to John Glenn returning to space aboard shuttle Discovery at age 77 (M)

headline.main: Still Among The Young At Heart

results.snippet: ALL but lost in the whirl of important issues, like which Senate candidate is proving to be rougher, was a recent report on how Federal agents arrested seven middle-aged New Yorkers on burglary and racketeering charges. It put the lie to the slander...
results.lead_paragraph: ALL but lost in the whirl of important issues, like which Senate candidate is proving to be rougher, was a recent report on how Federal agents arrested seven middle-aged New Yorkers on burglary and racketeering charges. It put the lie to the slander that the press never prints good news. If you are part of the fast-growing tribe that will never see 50 again, you had to be heartened by the exploits of this daring band, which included a few men who are taking a bead on 60. One of them even lives in a nursing home.

results.abstract: Ordinary mission for space shuttle Discovery assumes outsized importance because it will include John Glenn, who 36 years ago was first American to orbit Earth; Glenn, now 77, will be oldest person ever to fly in space; Glenn's encore flight is scheduled for launching on Oct 29; he will join crew of six other astronauts on nine-day mission during which they will conduct observations of solar physics, test new equipment for Hubble Space Telescope and conduct experiments in materials processing and biology; there has been some criticism of flight as blatant publicity ploy by National Aeronautics and Space Administration; deeper response has been awakening of submerged memories of Glenn's earlier flight, during cold war era, when Russians at first outpaced United States in space accomplishments; photos (L)

headline.main: For Glenn and the Nation, a Trip Back in Time

results.snippet: The countdown is set to begin tomorrow morning for a space flight that will not make history or any new heroes but has everything to do with history and an aging hero, John Glenn.    Thirty-six years after he rode a cramped Mercury capsule to become...
results.lead_paragraph: The countdown is set to begin tomorrow morning for a space flight that will not make history or any new heroes but has everything to do with history and an aging hero, John Glenn. Thirty-six years after he rode a cramped Mercury capsule to become the first American to orbit Earth, on Feb. 20, 1962, and 24 years after the trajectory of fame landed him in the United States Senate, Mr. Glenn will be suiting up again as an astronaut. At the age of 77, he will be the oldest person ever to fly in space, a hero of the cold war stepping forward this time as a role model for the geriatric generation -- and to satisfy an unending yearning.

results.abstract: Seven space shuttle Discovery astronauts, including Sen John Glenn, fly from Houston to Cape Canaveral for final preparations for nine-day mission that will be launched on October 29; Glenn expresses surprise at outpouring of interest in mission, which he hopes will lead to renewal of widespread public support for space exploration; he is returning to space, at age 77, for first time since historic flight in 1962, when he became first American to orbit Earth; photo (M)

headline.main: Countdown Begun, Glenn and Shuttle Crew Arrive

results.snippet: With the countdown clock running and all preparations on schedule here, the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery, including Senator John Glenn, flew in today from Houston to get ready for their nine-day mission, set to begin at 2 P.M. on...
results.lead_paragraph: With the countdown clock running and all preparations on schedule here, the seven astronauts of the space shuttle Discovery, including Senator John Glenn, flew in today from Houston to get ready for their nine-day mission, set to begin at 2 P.M. on Thursday. At a brief welcoming ceremony at the Kennedy Space Center landing strip, Mr. Glenn stepped down from a T-38 jet and told reporters, ''I have been pleasantly surprised at the outpouring of interest in this flight.'' He said he hoped it would lead to a renewal of widespread public support for space exploration.

results.abstract: Thirty-three people aged 55 to 84 go through astronaut camp for older people in Hutchinson, Kan; program is sponsored by Elderhostel, nonprofit program in Boston that provides educational adventures worldwide for adults aged 55 and over; many participants say their interest was piqued by scheduled return to space of Sen John Glenn and by age-related research aboard his shuttle mission; photos (L)

headline.main: A Space Adventure Tailored to Glenn's Contemporaries

results.snippet: In the commander's chair of a space shuttle, Robert Deupree safely brings his craft home after launching a satellite into orbit. Mission completed, Mr. Deupree and his crew emerge from the shuttle Falcon to the applause and cheers of well-wishers.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: In the commander's chair of a space shuttle, Robert Deupree safely brings his craft home after launching a satellite into orbit. Mission completed, Mr. Deupree and his crew emerge from the shuttle Falcon to the applause and cheers of well-wishers. Yes, it was a fictitious mission in a simulated shuttle, and it lasted only an hour instead of days. But the crew, average age 68, was pleased. After a week of abbreviated astronaut training, culminating in the intricate shuttle mission, they understood a little better what John Glenn must be feeling.

results.abstract: Interview with Thomas J O'Malley, former NASA rocket scientist who pushed button in 1962 launching John Glenn into space as first American to orbit earth; photo (M)

headline.main: At Cape Canaveral, Reliving the Grand Highs of '62

results.snippet: If he could see the place this week, Juan Ponce de Leon might wish he had taken a closer look when he passed this way in 1513 in his quest for the Fountain of Youth. There must be something here invigorating the likes of John Glenn and T. J....
results.lead_paragraph: If he could see the place this week, Juan Ponce de Leon might wish he had taken a closer look when he passed this way in 1513 in his quest for the Fountain of Youth. There must be something here invigorating the likes of John Glenn and T. J. O'Malley. Mr. Glenn, as everyone knows by now, is preparing to return to space on Thursday at an age -- 77 -- when many men are content to read Modern Maturity magazine after a gentle round of golf. Some of the spring in Mr. Glenn's step may be gone and his bones may be a little creaky, but here he is ready to board the space shuttle Discovery with other astronauts half his age to show the world, as he said in a recent interview, that the lives of older people need not be dictated by the calendar.

headline.main: New Space Venture Turns Back the Years

results.snippet: As John Glenn prepares to return to space tomorrow at age 77, he has said he hopes to show the world that the lives of older people need not be dictated by the calendar. The astronaut is not the only one coming back to the site of his 1962 space...
results.lead_paragraph: As John Glenn prepares to return to space tomorrow at age 77, he has said he hopes to show the world that the lives of older people need not be dictated by the calendar. The astronaut is not the only one coming back to the site of his 1962 space flight, when he became the first American to orbit the planet. Thomas J. O'Malley, who pressed a black button to start the Atlas booster's engines and send Mr. Glenn on his way in a Mercury capsule, is 83 now but still full of sass and gruff charm. He and many of those who shared the anxiety, thrill and glory of the first Glenn flight, including the three surviving members of the original astronaut corps, are gathering again at Cape Canaveral to sip at the fountain of their youth. ''Those were great days, and we survived them,'' Mr. O'Malley recalled.

results.abstract: Television news outfits, both broadcast and cable, are giving extensive coverage to John Glenn's return to space, and a variety of specials is being served up as well; photo (M)

headline.main: Covering John Glenn

results.snippet: Anyone wondering about the extent of interest in 77-year-old John Glenn's return to space, almost four decades after he became the first American to orbit the earth, could get an idea from this week's television listings.     Not only are all the...
results.lead_paragraph: Anyone wondering about the extent of interest in 77-year-old John Glenn's return to space, almost four decades after he became the first American to orbit the earth, could get an idea from this week's television listings. Not only are all the television news outfits, both broadcast and cable, covering Mr. Glenn's scheduled launching aboard the space shuttle Discovery tomorrow live, but a variety of specials is being served up all week.

results.abstract: Countdown preparations progress smoothly for launch of space shuttle Discovery as Sen John Glenn's return to space after 36 years draws huge and growing crowd to Cape Canaveral, Fla; turnout of 3,700 news people is thought to be largest since Apollo lunar flights; photos (M)d

headline.main: Glenn Draws Huge Crowd To View His Latest Flight

results.snippet: The machines, the weather and John Glenn himself were ''go'' today for launching as countdown preparations progressed smoothly toward the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for 2 P.M. on Thursday, on the most eagerly awaited space...
results.lead_paragraph: The machines, the weather and John Glenn himself were ''go'' today for launching as countdown preparations progressed smoothly toward the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery, scheduled for 2 P.M. on Thursday, on the most eagerly awaited space mission in years. All because of Mr. Glenn, returning to space after 36 years, crowds of well-wishers were already descending on the Kennedy Space Center here and were expected to swell into the hundreds of thousands. The turnout of 3,700 news people is thought to be the largest since the Apollo lunar flights. All the major television networks will be showing the liftoff live, something else that has not happened in a long time, not since 1988 with the first launching of a space shuttle after the Challenger explosion in 1986.

results.abstract: Article discusses Luigi R Marano, 77, challenging Democratic incumbent Assemblyman Peter J Abbate Jr in 49th Assembly District in Brooklyn (M)

headline.main: A Veteran Candidate Runs Once More, With Feeling

results.snippet: Sitting behind a bare desk in a busy campaign headquarters in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Luigi R. Marano, a veteran of generations of Republican campaigns in Brooklyn, discussed his return this year to electoral politics.    ''If John Glenn...
results.lead_paragraph: Sitting behind a bare desk in a busy campaign headquarters in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, Luigi R. Marano, a veteran of generations of Republican campaigns in Brooklyn, discussed his return this year to electoral politics. ''If John Glenn can go back into outer space,'' the 77-year-old Mr. Marano said, referring to the former astronaut and United States Senator, ''then I can go back to Albany.''

results.abstract: John Glenn, an astronaut again at 77, returns to orbit in space shuttle Discovery; after two suspenseful delays, shuttle's two rockets and three engines ignite in flames and billowing vapors and lift seven-member crew into orbit some 345 miles above Earth; estimated 250,000 visitors to Kennedy Space Center at Cape Canaveral and surrounding communities watch blastoff; Pres Clinton declares that Discovery flight--last mission before NASA begins launching International Space Station in December--is the end of an era: 'So John Glenn began this first phase of our space program, and he's ending it just before we start on the space station'; photo of astronauts: Chiaki Mukai, Steven Lindsey, Scott Parazynski, Stephen Robinson, Pedro Duque, Glenn and Curtis Brown Jr; photos of liftoff (L)

headline.kicker: GLENN RETURNS TO SPACE: THE OVERVIEW
headline.main: 36 Years Later, Glenn Lifts Off for His Space Encore

results.snippet: John Glenn, an astronaut again at 77, returned to orbit today in the space shuttle Discovery for a rendezvous with the memory of a time when exploits of early astronauts held the world in thrall and for a long-awaited encore, this time as the  oldest...
results.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, an astronaut again at 77, returned to orbit today in the space shuttle Discovery for a rendezvous with the memory of a time when exploits of early astronauts held the world in thrall and for a long-awaited encore, this time as the oldest traveler in outer space. At 2:19 P.M., after two suspenseful delays, the shuttle's two rockets and three engines ignited in flames and billowing vapors and lifted the seven-member crew -- including Mr. Glenn, the retiring Democratic Senator from Ohio and the first American to circle the planet -- into an orbit some 345 miles above Earth.

results.abstract: Caryn James Critic's Notebook on weeklong media drumbeat leading to John Glenn's return to space; photos (L)

headline.kicker: GLENN RETURNS TO SPACE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK
headline.main: After the Fuss, the Launching Does Look Magical

results.snippet: During the weeklong media drumbeat leading to John Glenn's voyage into space, the former astronaut Scott Carpenter described one benefit of the flight. As he told MSNBC, ''The nation gets to revisit a time of imagination and hope and magic.'' That...
results.lead_paragraph: During the weeklong media drumbeat leading to John Glenn's voyage into space, the former astronaut Scott Carpenter described one benefit of the flight. As he told MSNBC, ''The nation gets to revisit a time of imagination and hope and magic.'' That sounds more like a description of a Disney film than rocket science, yet it succinctly captures the gilded tone of the television coverage up to and including yesterday's high-profile launching. The networks and all-news channels quickly found their common theme: the return of an American hero. And after 10 months of wallowing in the Lewinsky sex scandal, you could almost feel their relief as they leaped on this wholesome story. In the last decade television news has virtually ignored space unless a satellite seemed about to tumble from the sky. But all week the network newscasts have been sounding the puffy theme of heroism, interviewing Mr. Glenn and doing features on his historic flight in 1962.

results.abstract: John Glenn's private campaign to fly into space again becomes public celebration, generating cheers of joy and relief at Kennedy Space Center, mobbed viewing areas and raucous beach parties; days before launching, party atmosphere builds as guests and visitors filter into area; all week, at receptions, barbecues and restaurants, former astronauts and old friends of Sen Glenn hold court with tales of the old days; photo (M)

headline.kicker: GLENN RETURNS TO SPACE: THE SCENE
headline.main: A Countdown to a Very Big Party With V.I.P.'s Galore

results.snippet: John Glenn's private campaign to fly into space again became a public celebration today, generating cheers of joy and relief at the Kennedy Space Center here, mobbed viewing areas and raucous beach barbecues.    As Mr. Glenn and his six crew mates...
results.lead_paragraph: John Glenn's private campaign to fly into space again became a public celebration today, generating cheers of joy and relief at the Kennedy Space Center here, mobbed viewing areas and raucous beach barbecues. As Mr. Glenn and his six crew mates roared into space aboard the shuttle Discovery, about the only things remaining private were their thoughts. Every movement, every word and every nuance related to the mission was reported to a public ready for good news in a time of scandal and economic uncertainty.

headline.main: QUOTATION OF THE DAY

results.snippet: ''Liftoff of Discovery with a crew of six astronaut heroes and one American legend.''    LISA MALONE, countdown commentator at Cape Canaveral.   [A1]
results.lead_paragraph: ''Liftoff of Discovery with a crew of six astronaut heroes and one American legend.'' LISA MALONE, countdown commentator at Cape Canaveral. [A1]

results.abstract: Man in the News profile of Sen John Glenn (M)

headline.main: GLENN RETURNS TO SPACE: Man in the News -- John Herschel Glenn Jr.; To the Stars, Again

results.snippet: Two weeks before the launching, John Glenn settled into a chair for an interview, one of many in the buildup to his return to space. He had been in training for the Discovery flight long enough to adopt the mien of an astronaut, forsaking senatorial...
results.lead_paragraph: Two weeks before the launching, John Glenn settled into a chair for an interview, one of many in the buildup to his return to space. He had been in training for the Discovery flight long enough to adopt the mien of an astronaut, forsaking senatorial togs for gray slacks and a polo shirt with the crew insignia. Here was a man, at 77, eager to get back into space. A national hero as the first American to orbit Earth, he had once made apprehensive Americans feel good again about themselves in those trying times of the cold war. Now he was getting a chance to relive some of the glory of the day that defined the rest of his life.
